column4: Textron raises 2021 profit view on rebounding business jet demand
column5: (Reuters) -Textron Inc on Thursday raised its full-year profit forecast, propelled by a rebound in demand for its small and medium business jets as accelerated COVID-19 vaccinations encourage more people to fly.
column6: Shares of Textron rose 3% to more than two-year high of $63.56 after the company also beat earnings estimates for the first quarter ended April 3.
column7: As more economies recuperate from the health crisis and return to growth, sales of small and mid-sized jets are expected to recover faster than that of larger and more expensive jets.
column8: Textron said it now expects 2021 adjusted earnings of $2.80 to $3 per share, up from the earlier forecast of $2.70 to $2.90.
column9: “Overall demand environment is more positive. More people are looking to acquire aircraft than we’ve seen in quite some time,” Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said in a post-earnings call with investors.
column10: Donnelly said demand is still predominantly driven by a lot of personal travel but “the corporate aviation departments are starting to come alive.”
column11: Textron’s business jet deliveries rose to 28 units in the first quarter, from 23 units a year earlier. Deliveries had fallen 14% in the prior quarter.
column12: Sales in the aviation division, the company’s biggest, fell marginally to $865 million from $872 million a year earlier due to lower demand for aftermarket servicing, compared with a 9.7% decline in the fourth quarter.
column13: Aviation’s order backlog at the end of the quarter rose $2.1 billion, from $1.6 billion in the fourth quarter. The unit, which makes Beechcraft and Cessna aircraft, contributed more than a third to the company’s total revenue in 2020.
column14: Total revenue rose 3.6% to $2.88 billion and beat Wall Street estimates of $2.73 billion, while profit tripled to $171 million. Adjusted earnings per share of 70 cents beat estimates of 47 cents.

column4: Textron profit more than triples
column5: April 29 (Reuters) - Business jet maker Textron Inc said its quarterly profit tripled on higher demand for Bell helicopters and specialized vehicles.
column6: The company’s net income rose to $171 million, or 75 cents per share, in the first quarter, from $50 million, or 22 cents per share, a year earlier.

column4: Textron to sell part of flight simulation unit to Canada's CAE for $40 million
column5: (Reuters) - Cessna business jet maker Textron Inc said on Wednesday it has agreed to sell a portion of its flight simulation and training business to Canada’s CAE Inc for $40 million in cash.
column6: The assets being sold include Textron’s flight simulator manufacturing operations in Montreal, as well as certain entities in France and Malaysia and a minority interest in a joint venture in Iceland.
column7: Textron’s flight simulation and training operations in Tampa, Florida are not included in the sale, the company said.
column8: The deal is expected to close during the fourth quarter of 2020 or in early 2021.

column4: Textron to sell part of flight simulation unit to Canada's CAE for $40 mln
column5: Nov 25 (Reuters) - Cessna business jet maker Textron Inc said on Wednesday it has agreed to sell a portion of its flight simulation and training business to Canada’s CAE Inc for $40 million in cash. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Cessna maker eyes fourth-quarter aviation profit on private plane rebound
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N expects a profitable fourth quarter for its aviation division on revived demand for private jets, after the maker of Beechcraft and Cessna planes reported a total 48% fall in quarterly profit due to the pandemic, CEO Scott Donnelly said on Thursday.
column6: Shares in the company rose more than 7% in morning trade.
column7: COVID-19 has battered global demand for travel, but private flights which carry fewer travelers are generally recovering faster than commercial airline traffic, fueling industry orders for pre-owned and new corporate planes.
column8: While Cessna jet deliveries are forecast to decline by between 30% and 40% in 2020 after corporate clients canceled aircraft orders or deferred deliveries, Donnelly said he expects to see some recovery during the last three months of the year.
column9: Textron Aviation’s order backlog at the end of the third quarter rose to $1.8 billion, from $1.4 billion during the second quarter.
column10: NetJets, the world’s largest private jet operator, placed orders in the third quarter and will likely place orders during the last three months of the year, as Textron Aviation eyes breaking even in 2020, Donnelly told analysts.
column11: “Certainly, we’re expecting a profitable Q4 and getting the business back to breakeven,” he said.
column12: Textron’s business jet deliveries fell 44% to 25 planes in the third quarter ended Oct. 3, but recovered from a 50% slump in the second quarter.
column13: The company’s net income fell 48% to $115 million, or 50 cents per share, in the quarter, but topped analysts’ estimate of 35 cents per share, according to IBES estimates from Refinitiv, partly helped by higher military sales at its Bell helicopters unit.

column4: Textron profit drops 48% as business jet deliveries slow down
column5: Oct 29 (Reuters) - Cessna business jets maker Textron Inc reported a 48% fall in quarterly profit as aircraft deliveries dropped during the coronavirus crisis.
column6: The company’s net income fell to $115 million, or 50 cents per share, in the third quarter ended Oct. 3, from $220 million, or 95 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Devika Syamnath)

column4: Textron expects business jet orders to pick up in 2021: CEO
column5: (Reuters) - Textron TXT.N expects business jet order activity to pick up in 2021 after a coronavirus-linked hit to demand, as private flights rebound and corporate America restarts capex commitments, Chief Executive Scott Donnelly said on Thursday.
column6: Executives and forecasters are seeing a rise in demand for business jet flights this summer due to demand from new private jet passengers, a pick-up in leisure trips and easing European travel restrictions.
column7: Textron, which also makes Bell helicopters and recreational side-by-side and all-terrain vehicles, isn’t seeing a cancellation of existing aircraft orders.
column8: Business jet deliveries, however, slumped 50% to 23 planes in the second quarter ended July 4.
column9: “The customers that were in our backlog have stayed in our backlog,” Donnelly told analysts. “And now we’re seeing that improve as demand comes back into the marketplace.”
column10: General Dynamics Corp GD.N, said on Wednesday it is seeing the appearance of an increase in demand for its Gulfstream corporate planes. Rival business jet maker Bombardier Inc. BBDb.TO reports earnings on Aug. 6.
column11: Donnelly said Textron was seeing more sales activity for turboprops and light jets, but added he expects to see the company's backlog for larger aircraft from Berkshire Hathaway Inc’s BRKa.N NetJets, a key customer, pick up during the back half of the year.
column12: Textron expects aviation deliveries to be down by between 30% and 40% in 2020, although deliveries would increase in the second half of the year on a sequential basis.
column13: Textron stock rose 4.8% in morning trading.

column4: Textron to cut jobs, stop making flight simulators at Montreal plant
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N said on Thursday it would suspend the production of flight simulators at its plant in Montreal, Canada, and cut up to 1,950 jobs across several business units as the coronavirus crisis hurts demand for air travel.
column6: The company also said it expects to see lower sales volumes for its Cessna business jets and airport ground support equipment over the next few months.
column7: “There has been a substantial decline in demand and order cancellations for flight simulators in light of the expected long-term impact of the pandemic on the commercial air transportation business,” the company said in a filing.
column8: Textron also said it would record pre-tax charges of $110 million to $130 million in the second quarter related to the restructuring.
column9: The company will continue to produce flight simulators for other fixed-wing aircraft and rotorcraft at its Tampa, Florida factory. (bit.ly/3dbUsMj)
column10: Textron, which also makes Bell helicopters, anticipates 2020 cash outflow in the range of $80 million to $95 million.
column11: The job cuts represent about 6% of Textron’s employees. The company had furloughed some 7,000 U.S.-based workers in March.

column4: Textron suspends production of commercial air transport simulators at Montreal plant
column5: June 18 (Reuters) - Textron Inc said on Thursday it would suspend the production of commercial air transport simulators at its plant in Montreal, Canada, as the coronavirus crisis hits demand.
column6: “There has been a substantial decline in demand and order cancellations for flight simulators in light of the expected long-term impact of the pandemic on the commercial air transportation business,” the company said in a filing.
column7: Textron said it would continue to produce flight simulators for other fixed-wing aircraft and rotorcraft at its Tampa, Florida factory. (bit.ly/3dbUsMj) (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Devika Syamnath)

column4: Textron Aviation furloughs thousands of U.S workers
column5: SEATTLE (Reuters) - Textron Aviation, a unit of Textron Inc TXT.N, announced furloughs for most of its U.S.-based workforce on Wednesday as concerns over depressed demand due to the spreading coronavirus ripples through global aviation.
column6: The $13.6 billion company, which makes Cessna aircraft, Bell helicopters and flight simulators, said a four-week furlough at its Aviation unit would fall into a March 23-May 29 timeframe.
column7: The furlough affects some 7,000 or more workers, a person familiar with the matter said.

column4: BRIEF-Textron Says CEO's 2019 Compensation Was $18.9 Mln Versus $13.95 Mln in 2018
column5: March 5 (Reuters) - Textron Inc:
column6: * TEXTRON INC SAYS CEO SCOTT DONNELLY’S FY 2019 TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS $18.9 MILLION VERSUS $13.95 MILLION IN FY 2018 - SEC FILING
column7: * TEXTRON INC SAYS CFO FRANK CONNOR’S FY 2019 TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS $6.7 MILLION VERSUS $5.2 MILLION IN FY 2018
column8: * TEXTRON INC SAYS FOR 2019, RATIO OF ANNUAL TOTAL COMPENSATION OF CEO TO ANNUAL TOTAL COMPENSATION OF MEDIAN EMPLOYEE WAS 191 TO 1 Source text: (bit.ly/32VbMBV) Further company coverage:

column4: Bombardier in talks to sell business-jet unit to Textron: WSJ
column5: (Reuters) - Canada’s Bombardier Inc is in talks to sell its business-jet unit to U.S. maker of Cessna jets, Textron Inc, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.
column6: The move will help the struggling Canadian train and plane maker to pare billions of dollars in debt, the report said.
column7: Bombardier’s shares have plunged more than 30% so far this year. On Jan. 16, company flagged a 2019 profit warning, citing problematic rail contracts, as well as warned of a potential write down in the value of a plane partnership with Europe’s planemaker Airbus.
column8: Bombardier declined comment on the WSJ report, but a source familiar with the company’s thinking told Reuters it was holding talks over both rail and aviation assets to keep all its options open.
column9: Acquiring Bombardier’s business jet unit would add the Global series of large-cabin aircraft to Textron’s portfolio, which mostly makes small- and medium-sized corporate planes.
column10: Analysts have said that a deal would expand the U.S. company’s aircraft offerings, allowing it to offer a complete family of jets to a wider range of customers.
column12: Shares of Textron rose more than 9%, while those of Bombardier’s were up over 10%.

column4: Bombardier in talks to sell business-jet unit to Textron - WSJ
column5: Feb 4 (Reuters) - Canada's Bombardier Inc is in talks to sell its business-jet unit to U.S. maker of Cessna jets, Textron Inc, the Wall Street Journal reported here, citing people familiar with the matter.
column6: The move will help the struggling Canadian train and plane maker to pare its debts, the report said. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)

column4: Textron to increase the number of Boeing 737 MAX simulators in production
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N will increase the number of 737 MAX simulators in production, its chief executive said on Wednesday, after Boeing Co BA.N recommended that pilots undergo training in a simulator replicating the model before flying the grounded plane.
column6: “We are going to increase the number of MAX simulators we have in production,” Chief Executive Scott Donnelly told analysts. He added that he continues to see order interest and “a little bit of an upside on the number of MAX sims.”
column7: The 737 MAX has been grounded since March 2019 after two fatal crashes and cannot return to service until regulators approve software changes and training plans.
column8: Textron's TRU training division competes with Montreal-based training specialist CAE Inc CAE.TO.
column9: Donnelly declined to comment on reports of Textron as a possible buyer for Bombardier Inc's BBDb.TO corporate plane-making business.
column10: Rhode Island-based Textron, which makes Cessna business jets, has been floated by some analysts as a logical buyer amid reports that the Canadian plane and train maker is weighing additional asset sales to pay down debt and fortify its balance sheet.
column11: “We see the articles and hear all the noise but we would not comment on any M&A activity,” Donnelly said.

column4: Textron to increase the number of Boeing 737 MAX simulators in production
column5: MONTREAL, Jan 29 (Reuters) - Textron Inc will increase the number of 737 MAX simulators in production, its chief executive said on Wednesday, after Boeing Co recommended that pilots undergo training in a simulator replicating the model before flying the grounded plane. “We are going to increase the number of MAX simulators we have in production,” Chief Executive Scott Donnelly told analysts. He added that he continues to see order interest and “a little bit of an upside on the number of MAX sims.”
column6: The 737 MAX has been grounded since March 2019 after two fatal crashes and cannot return to service until regulators approve software changes and training plans.
column7: Textron’s TRU training division competes with Montreal-based training specialist CAE Inc.

column4: Explosion at Kansas aircraft plant injures 15 people
column5: (Reuters) - At least 15 people were injured on Friday after a liquid nitrogen line exploded at a Textron Aviation plant near Wichita, Kansas, potentially setting back the launch of a new aircraft under development, county and company officials said.
column6: Emergency medical services took 11 people to the hospital, one of them suffering potentially serious injuries, Dr. John Gallagher, director of Sedgwick County EMS, told a news conference.
column7: Company officials said two of victims went to the hospital in private cars and two were treated at the scene.
column8: Injuries were limited because only a skeleton crew was on duty during the holidays, said Deputy Chief Daniel Wegner of the Sedgwick County Fire Department.
column9: The explosion in a 3-inch liquid nitrogen gas line also damaged a storage tank, causing nitrogen gas to vent out of the building, Wegner said.
column10: News video from the scene showed what appeared to be a steam cloud billowing out of the damaged building. The gas was not harmful, Wegner said.
column11: A second valve also ruptured, said Kate Flavin, a spokeswoman for Sedgwick County, and emergency crews vented nitrogen gas from the affected tanks before doing another search of the plant.
column12: No others were found injured and control of the facility was returned to Textron shortly after noon, but emergency crews remained on standby at the scene, she said.
column13: Damage was contained to Plant 3, a site for composite manufacturing and experimental aircraft fabrication including that of the SkyCourier, said Stephanie Harder, a spokeswoman for Textron.
column14: The SkyCourier, a utility turboprop under development, is due to enter service in 2020, Textron has previously said. Harder said it was too early to determine what damage the prototype aircraft under production may have suffered.
column15: Textron Aviation, a unit of Textron Inc TXT.N, makes Beechcraft and Cessna aircraft.
column16: The Wichita-area economy has long been supported by aircraft manufacturing. Boeing Co BA.N announced in January it would suspend production of its 737 Max jetliner, which has been grounded worldwide after two fatal crashes. That move affected workers at Spirit AeroSystems in Wichita, Boeing's top supplier, which produces the jet's fuselages.

column4: Textron expands parts business capabilities, eyes aftermarket services
column5: LAS VEGAS, Oct 21 (Reuters) - Textron Inc on Monday announced a further expansion of its global parts distribution facilities as corporate planemakers eye growth in their higher-margin aftermarket service businesses.
column6: Corporate plane makers are banking on sales of new products and maintenance packages to boost revenues, even as they introduce new models of corporate jets.
column7: Textron Aviation, which produces Cessna Aircraft, said it grew warehouse square footage at three U.S. locations by nearly 50%, to over 8,000 square feet. The U.S. expansion follows Textron’s plans to make parts more readily available to customers in Europe and Asia-Pacific earlier this year.
column8: Textron’s announcement comes ahead of the world’s largest business jet show, which kicks off on Tuesday, featuring new large corporate planes that can fly farther and an industry push toward sustainable aviation fuels.

column4: Textron exploring options for fuel tanks unit
column5: (Reuters) - Cessna business jets maker Textron Inc TXT.N said on Monday it will explore options for its unit that manufactures fuel tanks for vehicles, including a sale or a spinoff, as it focuses on its higher margin businesses.
column6: The company’s shares rose 3.13% to $48.50 before the bell.
column7: The unit, Kautex, is part of Textron’s industrial business, which reported a profit margin of 6.6% in the first six months of 2019, the lowest among the company’s four units.
column8: Textron’s total profit margin was about 10% for the same period.
column9: Bonn, Germany-based Kautex makes pressurized fuel tanks for cars, light trucks and all-terrain vehicles, and reported more than $2.3 billion in revenue in 2018.
column10: Kautex also makes selective catalytic reduction systems used to reduce emissions from diesel engines.
column11: Goldman Sachs & Co LLC is Textron’s financial adviser for the review.

column4: Textron exploring options for fuel tanks unit
column5: Aug 5 (Reuters) - Cessna business jets maker Textron Inc said on Monday it will explore options for its Kautex unit, a manufacturer of fuel tanks for vehicles, including a sale or a spin-off.
column6: Kautex had more than $2.3 billion in revenue in 2018. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: Textron sees final certification of Longitude jet in third quarter
column5: (This April 17 story corrects headline and first paragraph to say the certification is expected in the ‘third’ quarter, not the ‘second’)
column6: (Reuters) - Textron Inc said on Wednesday it expects the final certification of its newest Longitude business jet in the third quarter of 2019, after it was delayed for several months.
column7: The company is expecting major revenue growth in 2019 from the sales of the Longitude jet and said deliveries of the aircraft would begin in the third quarter of this year.
column8: “We continue to coordinate closely with the Federal Aviation Administration as our engineer group works to complete the underlying documentation that is required under the FAA’s design assurance process,” Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said.

column4: Textron sees final certification of Longitude jet in second quarter
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc said on Wednesday it expects the final certification of its newest Longitude business jet in the second quarter of 2019, after it was delayed for several months.
column6: The company is expecting major revenue growth in 2019 from the sales of the Longitude jet and said deliveries of the aircraft would begin in the third quarter of this year.
column7: “We continue to coordinate closely with the Federal Aviation Administration as our engineer group works to complete the underlying documentation that is required under the FAA’s design assurance process,” Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said.

column4: UPDATE 2-Textron profit beats on higher aircraft sales
column5: * Business jet deliveries rise to 44 in Q1 from 36 last year
column6: * Reaffirms full-year profit outlook (Adds analyst comment, share move)
column7: April 17 (Reuters) - Cessna business jet maker Textron Inc reported a higher-than-expected quarterly profit on Wednesday, benefiting from robust aircraft deliveries, sending its share up 1.6 percent in early trading.
column8: Business jet demand has been growing steadily in the United States, the world’s biggest market, on the back of an expanding economy and rising corporate profits.
column9: Textron said it delivered 44 jets in the first quarter ended March 30, up from 36 last year. Commercial turboprop deliveries rose to 44 aircraft from 29 last year.
column10: “We think this quarter has pretty much ticked all the boxes for Textron. Aviation growth has continued, with a positive book to bill in the quarter,” Vertical Research Partners analyst Robert Stallard said.
column11: Textron has faced delays in final certification of its newest super mid-size Longitude jet, which is expected to contribute a ‘big chunk’ to the company’s revenue growth in 2019.
column12: Analysts have warned that the certification delays from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration due to partial government shutdown followed by the regulator’s intense focus on re-certifying Boeing Co’s 737 MAX aircraft might impact sales growth at the company in the short.
column13: Though the aviation business was among the drivers for a profit beat, Textron’s revenue missed Wall Street estimates, hurt by lower sales in its systems unit, which makes tactical armored patrol vehicles.
column14: Textron re-affirmed its full-year profit outlook range of $3.55 to $3.75 per share.
column15: Sales in the company’s aviation business, its biggest, rose 12.3 percent to $1.13 billion in the first quarter, while sales in the systems unit fell more than 20 percent to $307 million.
column16: The company’s net income fell to $179 million in the quarter ended March 30 from $189 million a year earlier.
column17: Textron earned 76 cents per share, above analysts’ average estimate of 68 cents, according to Refinitiv data.
column18: Textron’s revenue fell 5.7 percent to $3.11 billion, below analysts’ estimates of $3.17 billion. (Reporting by Divya R and Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Textron's first-quarter revenue falls 5.7 percent
column5: April 17 (Reuters) - Textron Inc on Wednesday reported a 5.7 percent fall in quarterly revenue due to the divestiture of its tools and test equipment business.
column6: The company, which makes Cessna business jets, said net income fell to $179 million in the first quarter ended March 30 from $189 million a year earlier.
column7: On a per share basis, the company earned 76 cents in the quarter, compared with 72 cents last year.
column8: Textron’s revenue fell to $3.11 billion from $3.30 billion. (Reporting by Divya R and Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Strong business jet demand drives Textron's profit beat, shares rise
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N forecast 2019 profit above analysts' estimates on Thursday, after reporting stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter results on higher demand for its Cessna business jets, sending its shares up as much as 8.7 percent.
column6: Business jet demand is recovering in the United States, thanks to a strong economy and a tax windfall handed to Corporate America by President Donald Trump last year.
column7: “A big chunk of the growth in revenue we’ll see year-over-year is tied into the Longitude (business jet),” Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said on a post earnings call with analysts.
column8: The Cessna Citation Longitude jet received a provisional certification in the fourth quarter, allowing operators to begin flight training for deliveries in 2019, Donnelly said.
column9: It now awaits final certification from the Federal Aviation Administration that is pending due to U.S. government shutdown, the longest in the country’s history.
column10: “The aircraft is in a very good place. Production line is rolling,” Donnelly said.
column11: Textron is banking on its newest mid-sized business jet, Cessna Citation Longitude, to further bolster its luxury jet business.
column12: NetJets, the luxury plane unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc BRKa.N, announced a deal with Textron in October to buy up to 175 Longitudes and 150 Hemispheres jets. The company said it expects 2019 profit of $3.55 to $3.75 per share, surpassing the average analyst' estimate of $3.49 per share, according to Refinitiv data.
column13: In the fourth quarter, the company, which also makes Bell helicopters, said it delivered 63 business jets in the fourth quarter, up from 58 a year earlier. Turboprop aircraft deliveries also rose to 67 units from 45.
column14: That helped drive a 12 percent rise in revenue at the company’s main aviation unit. Total revenue, however, fell 6.6 percent to $3.75 billion due to weak demand for its Bell helicopters.
column15: The company reported net income of $246 million for the quarter ended Dec. 29, compared with a year-earlier loss when it booked a tax-related charge.
column16: Excluding items, Textron earned $1.15 per share, above analysts’ average estimate of 98 cents per share, according to Refinitiv data.

column4: Textron blames Arctic Cat buy for profit miss, shares fall 11 percent
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N posted a lower-than-expected quarterly profit on Thursday due to lingering problems at its industrial products unit that houses its recently acquired Arctic Cat all-terrain vehicle business, sending its shares down 11 percent.
column6: Investors worried the maker of Cessna business jets was struggling to integrate the business after the company said it was undergoing a “painful learning experience” in its efforts to add more customers at the retail level and manage discounting.
column7: Textron was one year behind schedule on booking gains from the Arctic Cat acquisition, Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said on a conference call, while pointing to poor management of the unit.
column8: “We went into this expecting to be able to generate accretion in year one. Obviously, that’s not going to happen,” he said.
column9: “When you have something like that going on, it creates enough chaos that drives down the operating performance.”
column10: Revenue at the aviation unit, the company’s biggest business, also fell about 2 percent, due to stagnant Cessna deliveries and a slump in turboprop sales.
column11: But that was dwarfed by a 10.7 percent drop in sales to $930 million in the industrial products unit, pulling down overall revenue well below the average analyst estimate.
column12: Textron said it expected to see a healthier fourth quarter for the industrial business, as the unit now has a “very good team in place” to help recover lost ground.
column13: The company last week replaced Kevin Holleran, in charge of Arctic Cat’s parent unit, with Scott Ernest, the head of its aviation business.
column14: Backlog in the aviation business rose to $1.8 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 29 from $1.6 billion in the prior quarter, the company said.
column15: Business jet demand is recovering in the United States, thanks to a tax windfall handed to Corporate America by President Donald Trump in January.
column16: “Just as Textron was poised to announce a meaningful improvement in the bizjet market, its plans get derailed by dirt buggies,” said Vertical Research Partners analyst Robert Stallard.
column17: The company narrowed its 2018 earnings per share forecast to a range of $3.20 to $3.30, from $3.15 to $3.35.
column18: The stock, last down 10.3 percent at $58.13, had risen about 14.5 percent this year, outperforming a 5.1 percent increase in the S&P 500 index .SPX.

column4: Textron says Arctic Cat acquisition hurt third-quarter profit
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N is one year behind schedule on benefiting from the acquisition of all-terrain vehicles maker Arctic Cat, the company said on an earnings call on Thursday, blaming the unit's management for "unfavorable operating performance".
column6: The company’s third quarter profit took a hit from weak sales at the unit.
column7: “When you have something like that going on at the business, it creates enough chaos that drives down the operating performance in total,” Chief Executive Scott Donnelly said.
column8: Earlier this month, Textron replaced Kevin Holleran, who was in charge of the unit that houses the Arctic Cat business, with Scott Ernest, the head of the company’s aviation unit.

column4: Textron says Arctic Cat acquisition hurt third-quarter profit
column5: Oct 18 (Reuters) - Textron Inc is one year behind schedule on benefiting from the acquisition of all-terrain vehicles maker Arctic Cat, the company said on an earnings call on Thursday, blaming the unit’s management for “unfavorable operating performance”.
column6: The company’s third quarter profit took a hit from weak sales at the unit.
column7: “When you have something like that going on at the business, it creates enough chaos that drives down the operating performance in total,” Chief Executive Scott Donnelly said.
column8: Earlier this month, Textron replaced Kevin Holleran, who was in charge of the unit that houses the Arctic Cat business, with Scott Ernest, the head of the company’s aviation unit. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: Textron profit misses on lower aircraft sales
column5: Oct 18 (Reuters) - Textron Inc on Thursday reported a lower-than-expected quarterly profit, partly due to lower sales of its turboprop aircraft.
column6: The Cessna jet maker’s income from continuing operations rose to $563 million, or $2.26 per share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 29 from $159 million, or 60 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Excluding the gain on the sale of a business, Textron earned 61 cents per share, below analysts’ average estimate of 76 cents per share, according to Refinitiv data.
column8: Total revenue fell about 8.2 percent to $3.20 billion. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Textron, NetJets strike deal for up to 325 Cessna planes
column5: ORLANDO, Fla. (Reuters) - NetJets, the luxury plane unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc BRKa.N, announced a deal on Monday to purchase up to 325 Cessna Citation business jets from Textron Inc's TXT.N aviation unit, one of the biggest orders unveiled at a major jet show this week in Orlando, Florida.
column6: Rob Scholl, a spokesman for Textron Aviation, said he expects NetJets to firm up the orders for up to 175 super-midsize Cessna Citation Longitude aircraft and up to 150 Cessna Citation Hemisphere aircraft in the coming weeks.
column7: Deliveries are expected in the fourth quarter of 2019.
column8: In a statement, NetJets said the Textron agreement could increase its Cessna Citations fleet, which it has operated since 1984, to more than 800 aircraft over the next 10 to 15 years.
column9: The Longitude will compete with the new longer-range, midsized Praetors launched by Embraer SA EMBR3.SA on Sunday and Bombardier Inc's BBDb.TO Challenger 350 and 650 aircraft.
column10: Planemakers and buyers were buzzing about the deal as they arrived in Orlando for the National Business Aviation Association’s flagship annual corporate jet show, which begins on Tuesday.
column11: Demand for luxury aircraft is seen rising thanks to a strong economy and tax cuts in the United States, the world’s largest market for private planes.
column12: The NetJets agreement is good news for French engine maker Safran SA SAF.PA, which has relied on sales of Cessna's Hemisphere aircraft, the newest member of the Citation jet family, for its Silvercrest engine.
column13: “NetJets is the market leader and gives a great deal of credibility to the aircraft and the engine,” Olivier Andries, chief executive of Safran Aircraft Engines, told Reuters by telephone.
column14: Development of the already-delayed engine was thrown off course last year when Safran reported a problem with a compressor during certain types of high-altitude test-flying.
column15: Safran has started producing redesigned parts and will start assembling them in early 2019, followed by ground tests during the second quarter to ensure the solution is working, Andries said.
column16: Last month Safran reached a financial settlement with French planemaker Dassault Aviation SA AVMD.PA, which scrapped plans for a new aircraft that was due to have been powered by Silvercrest. Dassault replaced the plan with a new model, the Falcon 6X, powered by engines built by Pratt & Whitney Canada, a unit of United Technologies Corp UTX.N.
column17: Dassault unveiled further details of the relaunched Falcon 6X in Orlando on Monday.

column4: Textron, NetJets strike deal for more than 300 Cessna planes
column5: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct 15 (Reuters) - NetJets, the luxury plane unit of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc, on Monday announced a deal to purchase up to 325 Cessna Citation business jets from Textron Inc’s aviation unit, one of the biggest orders unveiled at a major jet show this week in Orlando, Florida.
column6: Rob Scholl, a spokesman for Textron Aviation, said he expects NetJets to firm up the orders for up to 175 super-midsize Cessna Citation Longitude aircraft and up to 150 Cessna Citation Hemisphere aircraft in the coming weeks.
column7: Deliveries are expected in the fourth quarter of 2019.
column8: In a statement, NetJets said the Textron agreement could increase its Cessna Citations fleet, which it has operated since 1984, to more than 800 aircraft over the next 10 to 15 years.
column9: The Longitude will compete with the new longer-range, midsized Praetors launched by Embraer SA on Sunday and Bombardier Inc’s Challeger 350 and 650 aircraft.
column10: Planemakers and buyers were buzzing about the deal as they arrived in Orlando, Florida, for the National Business Aviation Association’s flagship annual corporate jet show, which begins on Tuesday.
column11: Demand for luxury aircraft is seen rising thanks to a strong economy and tax cuts in the United States, the world’s largest market for private planes.
column12: The NetJets agreement boosted shares of Textron and also came as a relief to French engine maker Safran SA, which has relied on sales of Cessna’s Hemisphere aircraft, the newest member of the Citation jet family, for its troubled Silvercrest engine.
column13: The deal could increase confidence in the Silvercrest engine made by Safran, which last month reached a financial settlement with Dassault Aviation SA over the engine’s production delays.
column14: French planemaker Dassault recently scrapped plans for a new aircraft that was due to have been powered by Silvercrest and replaced it with a new model, the Falcon 6X, powered by engines built by Pratt & Whitney Canada, a unit of United Technologies Corp.
column15: Dassault unveiled further details of the relaunched Falcon 6X in Orlando on Monday.
column16: Shares in Textron gained 1.64 percent $66.14 in U.S. trade on Monday. (Reporting by Allison Lampert in Orlando, Florida; additional reporting by Tim Hepher in Paris; writing by Tracy Rucinski; Editing by David Gregorio)

column4: Textron shares slip on order book concerns after profit beats view
column5: (Reuters) - Textron Inc TXT.N reported a higher-than-expected quarterly profit and raised its 2018 forecast on Wednesday, but its shares fell 5 percent as investors focused on the relative strength of its aviation business order book.
column6: Order books of business jet makers such as Textron are widely expected to get a bump from a stronger U.S. economy, tax cuts by the Trump administration and higher oil prices.
column7: However, the company’s book-to-bill ratio that measures orders against deliveries dropped to 1x in the second quarter from 1.4x in the preceding quarter, indicating a relative tightening of its backlog.
column8: Backlog in the business, which makes Cessna business jets and is the largest contributor to total revenue, was flat at $1.6 billion in the quarter compared with the preceding quarter.
column9: “We think aviation book-to-bill of 1x in face of expected improving end market is the reason for weakness,” Stephens Inc analyst Drew Lipke said.
column10: The company’s shares, which were up in premarket trade, reversed course as investors absorbed that the raise in the profit forecast was really in part due to tax cuts and not a bump in demand.
column11: Textron, which also makes Bell helicopters, said it now expects a full-year effective tax rate of about 19.5 percent, down from 22.5 percent.
column12: The Providence, Rhode Island-based company raised its 2018 earnings per share forecast to a range of $3.15 to $3.35, from $2.95 to $3.15.
column13: “The increased guidance reflects about 10 cents of a benefit due to a lower effective tax rate during the second quarter,” Lipke said.
column14: Textron sold 48 jets and 47 turboprops in the quarter, compared with 46 jets and 33 turboprops a year earlier, while Bell commercial helicopter deliveries nearly tripled to 57 units.
column15: Income from continuing operations jumped 46.4 percent to $224 million, or 87 cents per share.
column16: Total revenue rose 3.4 percent to $3.73 billion.
column17: Analysts on average had expected earnings of 70 cents per share, and revenue of $3.53 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

column4: Textron profit beats on higher business jet deliveries
column5: July 18 (Reuters) - Textron Inc on Wednesday reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit, helped by higher aircraft deliveries, and the Cessna business jet maker raised its 2018 earnings and cash flow forecasts.
column6: The company’s shares were up about 3 percent at $68.76 in premarket trading.
column7: Textron, which also makes Bell helicopters, said it now expects 2018 earnings per share of $3.15 to $3.35, compared with its previous forecast of $2.95 to $3.15.
column8: The company now expects cash flow from continuing operations in a range of $750 million to $850 million, up $50 million from its previous expectation.
column9: Textron said it sold 48 jets and 47 turboprops in the second quarter ended June 30, compared with 46 jets and 33 turboprops a year earlier.
column10: The Providence, Rhode Island-based company’s income from continuing operations rose to $224 million, or 87 cents per share, in the quarter, from $153 million, or 57 cents per share, a year earlier.
column11: Total revenue rose 3.4 percent to $3.73 billion.
column12: Analysts on average had expected second-quarter earnings of 70 cents per share, and revenue of $3.53 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Textron profit surges as corporate America buys more business jets
column5: (Reuters) - Cessna jets maker Textron Inc TXT.N reported a higher-than-expected quarterly profit on Wednesday, as President Trump's tax cuts encouraged corporate America to spend more on business jets.
column6: Shares of Textron, which also makes Bell helicopters, rose as much as 8.2 percent to hit a more than three-year high of $64.86 on results that surprised some company analysts.
column7: Demand for business jets was strong in the United States and improving in many international markets as global economies strengthen, Chief Executive Officer Scott Donnelly said.
column8: “I think that the (U.S.) tax reform, obviously, is part of it. More importantly, business confidence is strong. People are looking to invest,” said Donnelly.
column9: Worldwide business jet shipments have struggled to recover since the financial crisis, and last year were still only around half a peak of 1,317 hit in 2008.
column10: Textron’s quarterly numbers, which showed its backlog of orders that it has still to fulfill rising by $400 million to $1.6 billion, suggests the tide could be turning. Those numbers rose just $15 million in the fourth quarter.
column11: “Wow. We were not expecting this,” said Vertical Research Partners analyst Robert Stallard.
column12: “Not only was this a much stronger than expected operating quarter from Textron, we’ve also seen some movement on the portfolio which has arguably been long overdue.”
column13: Textron also unveiled the unexpected sale of its tools and test equipment business to Emerson Electric EMR.N for $810 million, as it prunes its industrial products unit, which makes blow-molded plastic fuel systems for cars, all-terrain vehicles, golf cars and snowmobiles.
column14: The Providence, Rhode Island-based Textron reaffirmed its full-year earnings forecast of $2.95 to $3.15 per share, including the impact of the divestiture.
column15: J.P. Morgan Securities analyst Seth Seifman said the company seems poised to raise its outlook later in the year.
column16: Textron said it was able to achieve significant margin improvement in the quarter with overall operating margins at 8.5 percent up from 7.1 percent a year earlier, partly due to favorable aircraft volume, mix and price.
column17: The company’s income from continuing operations rose to $189 million, or 72 cents per share, in the quarter, handily beating the Wall Street’s average estimate of 48 cents per share, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column18: Total revenue rose 6.6 percent to $3.30 billion, and was above the market expectation of $3.09 billion.

column4: Textron to sell tools business to Emerson Electric
column5: April 18 (Reuters) - Textron Inc said on Wednesday it would sell its tools and test equipment business to Emerson Electric Co for $810 million.
column6: The business makes electrical and utility tools, and test and measurement instruments. (Reporting by Arunima Banerjee in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D’Silva)
